reviewText:
Before I give my praise for what I consider one of my favourite shooters of the seventh console generation period, I must alert you to these facts:
If you don't have an existing Xbox Live account, or perhaps at least an email with Microsoft's Outlook or old Hotmail, the Games for Windows Live service this game remains tied to is probably gonna cause you an exceptional amount of trouble (As it has for the many writers of the Do Not Recommend reviews). And from what I'm told, good luck playing this game if you do run into trouble. I have an Xbox Live (Gold) account, so either I passed with flying colours or I was lucky.
There is however an easy workaround I've successfully tested to disabling GFWL on launch, which whilst will not let you play Multiplayer at all while using it, will allow you to enjoy the Singleplayer modes without the need for GFWL.

Firstly, head here to download the fix I located (Never have found the creator): http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Bulletstorm#Play_without_Games_for_Windows_-_LIVE
The contents of the .zip are xlive.dll" & "xlive.ini"
date: which will disable GFWL when copy-pasted into the game's files.\n\nSecondly
recommended: simply copy & paste the "xlive.dll" & "xlive.ini" here: Steam\SteamApps\common\Bulletstorm\Binaries\Win32. It doesn't overwrite anything
hoursPlayed:
so no need for backups or changes to adjust to (Other than the previously mentioned inability to play Multiplayer whilst these files are in Bulletstorm's Game Data).

And there you have it! You can enjoy the Singleplayer Campaign & Echo Missions without the need to use GFWL. I hope it helps you as much as it has me!

Although the game's default FOV is 85
voteText: which is within my personal comfort zone
helpfulPercent: I encountered constant screen tearing due to the capped 22-62fps smoothed frame-rate (Even with VSync turned off)
votesHelpful: and Mouse Smoothing is enabled & I don't believe it can be disabled via the Options Menu.\nPC Gaming Wiki however has instructions & a recommended tool; "BulletStormINIEditior" to allow you to edit the game's encrypted Config' files to uncap the frame-rate & adjust your numerous FOV levels. With it
votesTotal: I can now play at FOV 90 with no issues at all
votesFunny: I've had not one instance of screen tearing since and have turned Mouse Smoothing off outright. Here's the wiki page for more details: http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Bulletstorm\n\nIf you unfortunately cannot play the game

reviewText: For a start, it IS stupid fun. The dialogue is b-movie rogue hero stuff and progress is linear and direct, with no bother with an open world/roam anywhere playing field.\n\nSimple, yes, but the first surprise came with the highly polished gameplay. Controls are fluid and instantly familiar. Character movement is smooth and aiming is easy. Fun and combat variety come from the leash
recommended:
kicking, and sliding mechanics. Leash an enemy and yank them toward you, and they float in slow motion for a few moments while you kick or shoot them to pieces. The skill-based kill system is fun, encouraging you to be creative. What they also got right is they don't make it impossible to do this by overrunning you with hoards of enemies. While combat is well paced, you still have time to try out those various kills. The more creative you are, the more points you earn. Some of the skills are comical too (kill a burner by shooting his butt), and the whole game has a carefree, lighthearted feel to it.

The soundtrack is appropriate ranging from heavy metal guitar riffs when you die to sweeping orchestral melodies that set the stage for the upcoming action. The voice acting is top-notch as well, as the actors must have been cracking up at some of the lines they had to say.

Don't go into Bulletstorm hoping for a Mass Effect story or even a Call of Duty shooter, as you'll be disappointed. I went in with an open mind and got something that had been done before, yet fresh and exciting at the same time. Skillshots are extremely humorous and simultaneously gratifying, and a twisted, adult sense of humor kept me amused throughout. The game is crass, vulgar, graphically violent, and way over the top, but I smiled or laughed quite a bit and enjoyed it immensely.

reviewText:
It should only take one look at Bulletstorm's literally insulting advertisements to know the sort of game it is. A blood soaked, over-the-top story of a space pirate's revenge, it's crass, gratuitously violent, filled with more ♥♥♥♥ jokes than you can shake a stick at, and most of all absurdly enjoyable!

If you can get past the constant poop jokes and references to male genitalia, there's actually a fairly entertaining story hidden under the brohaha. As ex-military turned pirate, Grayson Hunt, the game opens with a swig of the bottle and a suicide crash into your previous general's ship. Through some miracle you both survive, and thus it becomes a race to see who will kill the other first as you endeavor to get off the overrun planet you've been stranded on. It's undeniably shallow in many places, but for what its worth the characters are surprisingly enjoyable despite their rough exteriors; often melodramatic, but always full of the tongue in cheek, self deprecating humor that pervades every area of the game.

Bulletstorm seems to operate on a philosophy that each moment needs to be more outrageous and spectacular than the last. The set pieces come at a whirlwind pace, and a scope that truly left me scrambling to pick my jaw up off the floor, as it takes on the challenge of besting itself throughout the admittedly brief 5-6 hour campaign. The idea of inserting downtime or filler into a game is one developer People May Fly have entirely no idea about, as for as short a game Bulletstorm is, the density of the action is so great that it's almost exhausting to try and take it all in. Aside from the terrible cliffhanger of an ending (likely setting up a sequel we'll never see), I wasn't the least bit unsatisfied with what I got out of the experience, and in fact would compare it favorably to a shooter that spends twice as long showing me half as much.

The idea that drives all of Bulletstorm is killing with skill. Sure, you can take an enemy down with a simple headshot, but if you want to rack up the points you need to get a little more creative than that. The amount of carnage you can cause after you discard the ideas of every shooter you've played before is truly ridiculous, from kicking enemies into man eating plants, creating massive explosive chains, and stringing enemies together with a single bullet, to any number of possibilities I couldn't even begin to list. The combat rewards originality and style above all else, and the encounters are designed in such a way that you can unleash your homicidal imagination like few games ever allow. All of this is tracked and rewards you points depending on the originality and impressiveness of your kill, creating a constant strive to never repeat the same thing and try for new and more insane combos throughout.

Gears of War might have been Epic's showcase for Unreal Engine 3, but Bulletstorm really puts it to use with a barrage of color and incredible explosions. The level of violence is in a league of its own, but it's so outrageous that it almost seems comical watching heads explode and enemies flying into fan blades (or maybe I've just turned that much more psychotic). It's an impressive visual accomplishment that sets a new bar for what can be done with the engine, with a fantastic array of effects and vistas that still hold up years later.

Bulletstorm is easily one of the most original and satisfying shooters I've played in a long time. The level of personality and creativity in every area of its design is absolutely brilliant, and its self aware nature hilarious and even charming at times (or as charming as characters whose favorite past time is inserting ♥♥♥♥" before every word can be). The shooting is both rewarding and inventive
date: rejecting the tried and true "aim for the head" mentality of so many others for its own unique brand of bloodshed. If you've ever found yourself feeling the strain of repetition with first-person shooters
recommended: you owe it to yourself to give Bulletstorm a shot. It's one of the most inventive and rewarding to come out in a long time
hoursPlayed: and demands an audience far bigger than the one it received.\n\nYou can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com]."

reviewText:
It appears that Steam is taking money for a game they know won't work.  The game still (as of Oct. 16, 2014) requires a Games for Windows Live (GFWL) account in order to play it.  GFWL is not working.  I have tried every fix I could find on the internet.  After each fix it still is not possible to set up a game account that works (no gamertag error over and over).  Even though steam and origin are both selling the game, it is not working for me on either service.

I realize EA should be the ones to patch and remove GFWL to fix this.  However, I am very disappointed Steam is selling it without ANY warnings or install requirements about GFWL in the game purchase listing. If it is possible to make the game work, they should have included the instructions on how.

UPDATE: Mar 10, 2016
games for windows live is still needed to make the game run.  In 2014 I was unable to create a gfwl account and game tag (both of which are needed). I tried several fixes back then and nothing worked.
On a whim tried again recently and was able to create the gfwl account and create a game tag.  Had to search around the xbox live site to do both but now it did work for me.

Games for windows live.... Solution for this problem is simple. Here are the steps:

1. Go to: http://www.xbox.com/en-US/live
2. Create an account.
3. Then start the game and login with your xbox live data.
4. Update Games for windows live.
5. Close the game and wait for the installation to finish
6. Restart game.
7. Login again
8. Enjoy the game.

It worked for me so I hope it works for you too.

reviewText:
It runs on GFWL. Not sure will the devs patch it or not. So GFWL haters, just skip this review and DON'T BUY IT. I bet even if GFWL is shut down, you can still play the single player campaign with an offline account. The multiplayer community is dead anyway, so not a big deal here.

A linear FPS with a lot of action! If you're playing this like classic FPS, you're doing it wrong. The main action in this game is leash and kick. The leash is a weapon attached to your hand, used for pulling objects or enemies towards you.

It is fun to kick enemies into spikes, leash a barrel and kicking them to enemies, and doing many other cool stuff you can do to the environment.

Weapon variety is just nice, you get all sorts of weapons as you progress in the game, like guns that shoot bouncing canon balls, and gun that shoot fireworks.

The graphic is cool, some nice scenery in here. All the actions are cool, the plot and conversations are funny at times. From start to the end, you are never alone. There will always be a companion that follows you and helps you progress.

The multiplayer mode is fun, but only if you have a friend to play with. The community is pretty much dead. Although multiplayer supports up to 4 players, I think 2 players is just nice, you can plan your skillshots with your friend without wasting too many kills.

A lot of dirty languages and bloody violence. My favorite quote in this game is Stop following me

reviewText:
I've come to a conclusion: Bulletstorm wasn't so much developed as it was raised on human growth hormones and taught the English language by a group of sailors and truck drivers. It was also shown every '80s action and sci-fi movie ever made about a dozen times, given a bottle of whiskey, handed a gun and instructed to shoot anything that moves.

The people who clearly felt that the first-person shooter genre was skimping on the S" in "FPS" and taking itself too seriously birthed it; the sort who've made the likes of Painkiller and published Unreal Tournament and Gears of War. It's clear in everything from its distinctive style to its disregard for the plausible.

reviewText:
Wow...what a gory action-packed rollercoaster ride ^^

You like good storys, deep characters and good writing?
Um...then you're totally wrong here.

This is an action-game which gives you no time for a deep breath. You will be running und gunning down enemies...but not just that, you will (and want to) do that the most creative way you can think of.
Throwing an enemy into the air and kicking him into some spikes at a wall? Check.
Shooting a sniper-rifle and lead the bullet manually into the balls of an enemy to get extra points? Check.
Getting extra points when killing an enemy while you're drunk? Check.

This game has all of the above and more, the pacing is great, the ideas are crazy, creative and lots of fun. It also has some nice (and some less good) oneliners.
The Story? Meh....you're some guy, chasing some bad guy, nothing you will keep in mind.

This feels like on of these testosterone-packed 80s action-movies, and even tops them.

If you like FPS and creative ways of killing enemies (in a gory way) then get this, it's quite fun.

reviewText: Despite the fact that the game didn't really sell well I can't emphasize how much fun it is. It has an interesting story, some of the best looking environments I've ever seen in a game, over the top yet entertaining dialog but the one thing that makes this game awesome: The game play. There is something so satisfying about kicking someone off the top of a platform, throwing people into spikes, shooting people in the nuts while at the same time getting rewarded for it the entire time. The game play is a feedback loop of awesome.\n\nI bought the game when it came out, and I've probably played through it 5-6 times and I can see myself easily enjoying another 5-6. If you're on the fence, buy this game,  you won't regret it.

reviewText:
Fast-paced & aggressively entertaining // Recommended for those seeking a solid shooter
+ Voice-acting, while not given the greatest dialogue, is nevertheless well-performed
+ Visuals have aged well and look fantastic; overall presentation really holds up to today's audience
+ Kicking and temporary gravity suspension elements work flawlessly; really makes for some creative kills
+ Gunplay is polished and satisfying; hit detection works adequately and one's shots really feel like they pack a punch
+ Environment is wonderfully involved with combat, and this only adds to the myriad possible ways that enemies can be disposed of; enemy mobs can be kicked into shattered rebar, thrown off of ledges, tossed into electrical wiring, and much more
+ Leash mechanics do much to make up for the limited weapon selection, and adds a unique functionality to the FPS-style of combat
+ Skillshots and experience points work well to incentivize one's creativity in disposing of enemies, and your statistics can be explored at drop boxes
+ Boasts a very fast pace that is broken only by (somewhat) frequent cutscenes; the game is certainly not boring
+ Firearms showcase neat designs and creative functionality
+ Characters certainly have a lot of personality; not a lot of real development to boast of, but they manage to not be boring
+ Drop boxes scattered throughout allow the purchase of weapon upgrades, ammunition, and more; they are frequently enough encountered to be convenient, but well enough spaced in that the game isn't holding the player's hand

- This game requires Games For Windows Live
- This game requires Games For Windows Live
- This game requires Games For Windows Live
- Lip sync and facial animations are atrocious
- Plot is generally weak and uninspired
- Multiplayer appears to be completely dead and unpopulated

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements, and I also have a budding YouTube Channel for those interested. Thanks for reading!

reviewText: This game uses Games for Windows Live - avoid like the plague. The client is very picky with connectivity and if you are using an n-router to connect several devices with NAT chances are that you will not be able to even start playing the game. My 39 minutes on record were spent playing with the firewall and router setup to get past the starting screen (unsuccessfully).\n\nTo be honest, I don't pay for things to jump through hoops; that is fine if you get your game from TPB, but it's a no-no to be treated like a crook after having spent your money. Save your fiver (if you are going to get this in a seasonal sales buying spree, like I did) and spend it on a nice drink or in a strip club. Because single moms need to make a living, too.

reviewText:
UPDATE!  It's now running in Origin.  Here's what I had to do:  I think I logged into my existing Windows LIve account and got it to do an update.  I had to use task manager to manually kill the game when prompted so it would finish the update.  I did this twice.  Now it seems to work in Origin and it logs into Windows Live automatically each time I start.  It's an UT3 engine game so my joystick screws it up.  I have to plug it in after the game starts otherwise my character just spins around in circles.  Happens for all UT3 engine games for me.  NOW THE GAMEPLAY:  Linear shooter but entertaining.  Graphics are typical UT3 engine and are quite nice.  No bugs and framerate is nice.  There is a story enough to keep you entertained and the levels are good but nothing stands out other than the visual.  Assault rifle seems underpowered but the other weapons are a nice balance.  Each situation makes you think about which weapon to use for the best effect.  BOTTOM LINE:  I would NOT buy this again based on extreme difficulty of installing it.  Stupendously difficult with no warnings of what is needed to get it to work.  If you can get it running, it's worth it if you want an OK entertaining shooter single player game.  I will not go online or rate the MP version of it.  So the single player is OK, but the extreme installation difficulty in my opinion makes this a game not to buy.  You have been warned.

UPDATE!  right click, register game.  Log it into your origin account.  Where does it say to do this?  I'll keep you posted.  It looks like it is available under my origin software.  Nowhere did it say to do this when launching the game!  Nowhere! LOL!  It's reinstalling under origin over 7GB!

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.  MICROSOFT, STEAM, GIVE ME A REFUND!

reviewText: An underrated gem. Most reviewers who played it at the time of its release quite simply did NOT understand what the game was all about, unfairly expecting it to be an old school shoot 'em up a la Painkiller. What we got instead is a very unique puzzle shooter that rewards you for creative kills and unique combos. Refreshingly colorful graphics and a nice degree of control over your character's movement are icing on the cake.

reviewText:
Okay, let's get the Games for Windows Live (GFWL) thing out of the way. When I started the game, I was asked to login to GFWL (I already have a profile I have used for other games). I logged in, and GFWL downloaded an update that required me to restart the game. Restarted, and was able to login and play without issue.

On to the review:
Bulletstorm is a superb shooter, with some unique mechanics, SUPER colorful environments and great weapons. I would even say that it is worth the asking price, except the multiplayer is barely populated, making the single-player campaign the primary draw.

+ The kick and slide mechanics are first rate, and easy to execute. You'll be sliding around in no time.
+ The leash" mechanic is also fun
date: though Red Faction Armageddon does the same thing better and with more variety\n+ The assortment of weapons is great
recommended: each requiring different methods to execute kills. My favorite was the homing sniper rifle; fire a shot
hoursPlayed: and you control the bullet with the mouse
voteText: guiding it around cover to kill enemies!\n+ The level design is good if linear. Don't be expecting alternate routes to go anywhere - there aren't any - but the path twists and turns enough so that directionality becomes confused.\n+ Though there are plenty of check-points
helpfulPercent: the game can be very hard if you want it to be.\n+ Plenty of variety in the enemies you fight
votesHelpful: with lots of mini-bosses even on Normal difficulty.\n+ The graphics are COLORFUL. The opening levels happen aboard a ship
votesTotal: and feel confined
votesFunny: but once you get out into the countryside and city
commentsCount: the vibrant color will hit you in the face. Detail and design of the graphics is great too. Some of the enviroments reminded me of a sun-lit Bioshock.\n+ Bulletstorm is easy on system resources
column16: making this game playable on a lot of machines. I never saw more than 500MB of video memory used; most of the time it hovered around 250-375MB\n+ People probably don't buy shooters for the voice-acting
column17: but it is very good
column18: especially the always-excellent Jennifer Hale.\n+ The single-player story embraces an entire genre of B-movie action stereotypes. Everyone fully commits
column19: and the game succeeds well at it.\n\n- Few people in multiplayer. Get some friends together
column20: and I'm told it will still work. But don't purchase Bulletstorm thinking you'll be able to join random online matches. I wasn't able to find any.\n- With the multiplayer a dead end
column21: the single-player campaign needs to carry the game's appeal. And it is very appealing
column22:
but it is too short. My first play-through clocked in at 8.9 hours. Replayability appeal relies on upping the difficulty and "restricting" yourself to specific weapons.
- No manual save system. The entire game is saved via checkpoints.
- The final boss is a series of QuickTime events. Always knock a point off for that. There are several non-QTE bosses in the game; I guess this is just how the developers wanted the game to end.

Not everyone has the GFWL issue; I suppose I was one of the lucky ones. Lucky indeed that I was able to play Bulletstorm. As a shooter
column23: it carries my highest recommendation. But get it on sale just in case GFWL screws you over; then you won't have wasted much money.*\n\n*Early reports indicate that users on Windows 10 no longer have the GFWL issue. I'm on Windows 7 x64."

reviewText:
I remember the advertising campaign for this game in form of Duty Calls, a parody of modern corridor shooters.
The ultimate joke here is that Bulletstorm is a typical modern corridor shooter, done along the same pattern Duty Calls demo had been done.
It's a corridor shooter done right. It's a hell of a competent title in everything it does. The gunplay is great and environments are varied. The gameplay isn't made of obvious fighting/idle segments (arenas, corridors).

And when this formula starts to get boring, the game ends with a typical cliff hanger. There's no reason not to play this game. It's intense, enjoyable and not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

reviewText: This will be my second time owning this game as I previously owned it back when I used to play consoles...Yes I like it that much! Bulletstorm is a wild ride of a game letting you kill your enemies in all sorts of wacky ways combined with a heart felt story of redemption. The game itself I feel plays a lot like Serious Sam with everything being way over the top characters, guns, kills, enemies... But isn't that exactly as we like it!!! Graphics have aged well as I found myself pausing multiple times to take screenshots of the beautiful scenery. The character designs look familiar to Gears of War" but from a first person point of view. Understandable as it's made by the same developers. But I like the designs so this is all good! The amount of combos you can do between the energy leash
hoursPlayed: and the multiple settings on each of your guns. If you're not having fun with this game you're just not trying hard enough because it is effortless. Just experiment with the tools that the game gives you and you're bound to have a blast!"

reviewText: Folks, Live Gaming for Windows sucks. I get it, but once you get it installed and setup (takes a little effort), this game is really, really worth playing. Everything about it is just awesome. The mechanics, the weapons, the characters and the best part, the dialogue. Yes, the dialogue is what REALLY makes this game. Hats off to the writers because it's pretty amazing. This title is worth owning and I worry for the day when I'm no longer able to play it due to the limitations of Live for Windows.\n\nIn the meantime, please, heed my advice and get this game and slog through the Live setup. It's sooooo worth it.

reviewText:
Bulletstorm is one of those Rare games which hits the spot for actually doing something skillful rather than just the normal shoot stuff First Person Shooter, unfortunatly the initial sales were not good for the game and as such a sequel has not made an appearance.

None the less it is an extremely enjoyable game with a good Single Player campaign a Friends Challege Games known as Echos (Try to beat each others score) and a Co-Op wave mode for up to 4 players.

Many people however have turned down the game by the presence of GFWL which although most consider awful and something to avoid does not mean you should not buy this game. If you have an Xbox then you should try there as it is also available there aswell if you have doubts over GFWL.

GFWL also to some people think it is turned off for good, it is not, the Marketplace has been turned off and the serviced switched over into Xbox Live systems.

As a warning this is a old game and people with newer systems should bear in mind that it might not work first time run.

The forums here on steam have a number of fixes for people struggling to get it working, go check them out if your having problems.

reviewText: An FPS game that is a leap in the right direction.  Though still plagued by challenge ruining health regeneration, Bulletstorm rewards you for destroying your enemies by utilizing impressive weapon efficiency, leashing and kicking them into environmental hazards, or a little of both!  Doing this earns you efficiency points which buy you ammo and weapon upgrades, so if you play this game in the boring, tedious mindset of Call of Duty or Halo, you'll find yourself high and dry very quickly.  The action just keeps on coming, offering widely varied environments with a ton of different hazards and eye catching visuals, which also tends to demand a bit more out of your hardware in return.  The game may not be difficult at all and the story may be pretty generic and predictable, but that doesn't seem to be the game's focus, which becomes obvious when you hear endless, hilariously juvenile lines like, I'll kill your ♥♥♥♥!" It's 8 hours of stupid
date: adrenaline fueled fun and I ♥♥♥♥ing loved it."

reviewText:
One of my favorite FPS' ever. Brutally fun to play. I love that there are many styles of killing. You can really mix things up and have your own playing style. I love that you are only able to re-arm yourself based on your kill style points, it really makes you more aware of how you are playing. Survival of the fittest :P

The characters are pretty straight-forward but I have to admit that for being a pretty foul-languaged person by nature, I still learned some new insults and swear-words. This pleased me greatly. I really love using my leash ability to yank infected bad guys into broken spkey walls and objects. There is something satisfying about kicking the ♥♥♥♥ out of bad guys and watching them splatter into cactus'.

This is a classic must own videogame for any shooter fan. My only disappointment is that the follow up Bulletstorm 2 seems to have fallen to the wayside (which is a shame because this would make a great series to continue). It's just a fun game that doesn't take itself too seriously and focuses more on being fun to play than anything else which makes it a winner in my book.

10/10 easily replayable

reviewText: The fact steam are selling this game is absolutely ridiculous. It won't work properly, due to Games For Windows Live (GFWL). It took me about to hours to get games for windows live working on my computer. It then took a further hour to get a working account going (I made two in total, and neither are fully working STILL). Finally I had reached the point where I could open bulletstorm, and that I could play the game. Or so i thought. I hadn't even reached the main menu when GFWL told me I needed to log in to play online. I logged in, and there was an error. I tried on both accounts. Since this was only necessary for online playing, I decided I would disconnect from all internet and restart my computer. I opened the game in offline mode with no internet connections, and GFWL STILL wouldn't let me access the game. Sort this out steam, it isn't fair for you to steal our money for absolutely no gameplay. I paid good money and all I got out of it is the names of the game's producers and a bad excuse for a online game provider.

reviewText:
Bulletstorm is that over-the-top, crude, fun, adrenaline soaked game that only comes along once every few years.
Bulletstorm shuns away from many of the modern trends in FPS games. Rather than mimic many of the popular tactical FPS games that populate store shelves every year, it embraces the FPS genre’s roots. It shows more influences from games such as Duke Nukem (not forever) and Doom rather than Call of Duty. One example being the gameplay is fast paced and score-point focused.  The player is rewarded with score points for the more outrageous and over the top moves in dispatching the alien/enemy hordes. As player’s point’s increase, the player can unlock new abilities and moves that help keep the gameplay from growing too stale in its short running time.
Another example of old school gameplay is the cover system. It’s similar to the Serious Sam games, that being cover is optional and not a requirement for advancement. In many areas the player can go in guns blazing and survive. With fast paced fun retro style gameplay and average beat time of 8+hours for main story*, there’s sure to be some enjoyment had for most FPS gamers.  Although a few words of caution much like Duke & Doom, Bulletstorm is a game solely for mature audiences. It has a strong focus on violence and profanity that would make a sailor blush. If neither of these things bother you, which I can’t imagine they would if you’re reading this page. Then do yourself a favor and try it out. With its age, it is on sale frequently for sub $10 pricing.

Overall Rating = 87

Best Regards,


Drakesvg

Bulletstorm = How Long to Beat
http://www.howlongtobeat.com/game.php?id=1383

reviewText: Bulletstorm is a visual novel featuring semi-static manhwa-style character images, and focused on shooting text logs. Using the mouse and keyboard, the player interacts with the Planet Stygia's main computer to shoot log entries, communicate with the AIs, and occasionally enter commands directly into the vessel's computer system. At any time in the game, the player can save their game, adjust options, etc.\n\nThe main user interface allows the player to shoot through various diaries and letters that reveal the game's backstory and insight into its many (deceased) characters. For the most part, navigating this interface is similar to navigating a basic e-mail system, in that messages are chronologically arranged and searchable. They are grouped in usually numbered blocks"

reviewText:
An entertaining first-person shooter of immediate impact which retains much from the Gears of War series, like the simple yet efficient combat system.
The eccessive linearity of gameplay is avoided by funny, creative and rewarding killing combos, involving an unconventional weapon arsenal and well designed enemies with fluent and clear animations. Even if single player campaing is way too easy and offers less than 10 hours of fun, the game experience is protracted in coop and multiplayer modes.

78/100

reviewText:
From having to crack the game to get rid of the XBox Live crap (Which does not work at all for me), to an underwhelming game experience, I completed it in under 4 hours.

Not worthy of your time nor money.

Graphics: Comparable to mid-generation XBOX 360 titles. You can look at it, but don't expect to see graphical effects putting you in awe.
Sound: Meh! The music is generic, the sound effects .. exist? The gun sounds are lacking some kind of kick.
Story: This is not the type of game you play for the story. There is one, it's not interesting, but it keeps out of your way enough so you can slaughter enemies.
Gameplay: They feel dated, even with the somewhat unique mechanic of being able to kick enemies away or pull them towards you, which you can use to send them flying into giant cacti. Seriously, those green ♥♥♥♥ers are everywhere. It's fun at first, but it gets old quick. Sometimes it's not a cactus but some electric cables. Further, the game makes heavy use of scripted events. You can't even jump. You can run and slide, but that's it. The scripts sometimes like to fail, I had to reload my savegame a bunch of times to 'fix' some event not occuring or me being stuck because the script didn't expect me to slide through it.

So, no, don't buy it.

reviewText:
Note: Bulletstorm makes for a very hard recommendation since it requires Games For Windows Live which will shutdown in July 2014 and likely make this game literally impossible to play. Also, there's no multiplayer community and the multiplayer gametype REQUIRES good team work, so unless you have some competent friends willing to participate in team skill kills, don't bother.

Otherwise, It's a linear, story based shooter focused killing enemies in stylish fashion for points. The points are less a upgrade currency, and more a stockpile currency as you need points to restock ammo. It is however, built in the story as a sort of judgement system, but you can't fail for a low score and is nothing like the Capcom style of system that ranks you.

Gunplay is very solid, and many guns like the revolver, sniper rifle, flail gun and drill gun (I forget the actual names) are very satisfying to shoot. The carbine that you're stuck with is a little less satisfying and doesn't have that spot on accuracy like you'd expect from shooting a carbine in most modern style shooters (a bit like the G36C in COD4, but without the accuracy you would expect if you shot semi-auto). It can however be annoying to try to pull of specific skillshots as some enemies can resist your lash and sometimes you can't kick an enemy to the exact spot you want. Because of this, most players will not be able to experience all the skillshots without looking up videos.

I'm not a great reviewer of story, so I can't say The story is good/bad"
date: though story will be the secondary reason for playing this game since it's a relatively short campaign with no multiplayer base. The story evokes similarities to Spec Ops: The Line
recommended: but it feels less about blaming the player and more about blaming the character you play. Ending is a bit disappointing as it hints at a sequel and playing it this late
hoursPlayed: I'm pretty sure there's no sequel planned.\n\nI enjoyed my short romp with it and if you can get it real cheap (No more than $10) and intend to play it to completion before GWFL is closed then only in that case is it worth it. If you have it already and have it finished
voteText: it is worth giving it a decent play
helpfulPercent: as I was able to finish it in two sittings."

reviewText:
This game is honest to God great. Everything is comically over the top intense, and the writing is done well enough to support it. The kill with skill thing sounded pretty dumb, but it's a really fun process and makes you try to use the entire spectrum of weapons, rather than just sticking with two. The game looks good, sounds good, plays well and made me chuckle over the conversation.
Mulitplayer is also pretty ♥♥♥♥in' cool. Arena waves with conditional kills really focus you and your partner to work together to maximize points.

Buy or some other how get this game and play it. You will certainly enjoy it.

reviewText:
Bulletstorm is an awesome fast-paced action FPS where you just simply kick ♥♥♥!
Play as space bounty hunter Grayson Hunt with your fellow shipmates that soon meet their doom, tagging along with one survivor, Ishi, and later an ♥♥♥-kicker of a girl Trish.
This game takes place on a planet with a very Mad Max / Borderlands-like atmosphere. You've got crazy psychos with a huge arsenal trying to mow you down with their rifles, machine guns, and rocket launchers, not to mentioned a ♥♥♥♥♥♥-bag antagonist that was once your commander. I love how fast the game is, while keeping up with it's stylized point system. The cooler your kill-shots, the higher the score and better rewards! There is also a great multiplayer addition to the game that enhances teamwork experiences.
Bludgeon, torture, swap, burn, vaporize, and humiliate! If this game had it's own dictionary, these words would be in them! Shoot and kill your way through fun hours of humor and bad-assity (if that's not a word, then it is now)

reviewText: Bulletstorm is the game that Duke Nukem should have been. One of the best First Person Shooters I have played in a long time, the campaign mode was ten hours of non-stop fun and laughter. With nearly 200 different achievements for killing enemies in different ways, the gameplay never ever gets boring. The game utilizes slow-motion in an effective and maddeningly addictive way.\n\nBulletstorm feels like a cheesy sci-fi action movie, only with more ♥♥♥♥ jokes. Still, there are a few moments near the end of the game where the antagonist teases the protagonist about all the innocent women and children" that he has killed in order to get to his true enemy. Few games ever mention this concept of collateral damage. Amidst a swarm of juvenille humor and inventive cursing
date: there is more soul in Bulletstorm than one would ever expect to find in a modern-day shooter."

reviewText:
I have previously played this game on a friends account and absolutely loved it.  The gameplay was fresh, the humour was cheesy and expected, but spot on, and everything felt fun.  I could not remember finishing it though, so I bought a copy for myself during the sale and attempted to install it.  Sadly for ages I was unable to play the game due to GFWL not updating properly.  This was a widespread issue, that at long last has finally been fixed.

I would highly recommend this game; it has mechanics that you will eventually get tired of, sure, and it doesn't have INFINITE replay value, but nothing quite beats the fun and violence this game offers when you need a pick-me-up after a tough day at school or work.

If you can grab it on sale, like it is right now for under £4, then it's an absolute steal.  Don't pass up the chance and kick yourself, when you could be kicking some random guy up into the air.

reviewText:
Let's talk about how ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ great Bulletstorm is.

Yes, it has it's problems, like sticking you with the boring assault rifle for far too long, it's too short, it goes too heavy on the cursing early (but evens out after an hour or so) and buying ammo all the time prevents you from going truly nuts with the skillshots.

But ♥♥♥♥ all that.  Bulletstorm is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fun as hell.  It takes the ridiculousness of FPS games, dials it up to 11 and just goes crazy with it. Skillshots are great because it forces you to do more than just headshot everyone, 95% of the weapons are cool as hell in a sadistic Ratchet and Clank kind of way and it's genuinely funny.

It's a damn shame we'll never get another Bulletstorm game because that ending leaves you wanting more but at least we'll always have Butterdick Jones and his heavenly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ machine to keep us company.

reviewText: bulletstorm is a fast paced shooter game filled with awesoem gore, bullets flying everywhere. alone with a variety of weapons you unlock whilst playing, there are a ton of different kill types you can make and the game encourages you to find all of them. The story itself was made as nothing more but to keep you wondering what could possibly happen next that would surprise you and it may not deliver but the humor within the games cutscenes and slow-walk sections can really brighten the mood especially with Nolan North behind the voice of the Vulgar protagonist along with his systematically altered remaining crewmate. Bulletstorm is an all out fun bloodbath and it's a shame that the sequel was canned because I believe that this game is our shining star among the titles from a few years ago

reviewText:
Have you ever wanted to step into the boots of a wanted Space Pirate hell bent on destroying an evil psychopathic war criminal no matter to cost or how many people or mutants stand in your way? Then this might just be the game for you.

First off this game is fantastic; from start to finish I had unending amounts of fun. You should buy this game and enjoy the ride. The action s explosive from the get go, you literally kick the crap out of everything you see. No metaphor here, you actually kick people into walls, spikes, fires, pretty much anything that would kill them dead. And that’s not mentioning the ability to fling them through the air using some future tech whip.

Also the guns, they are crazy fun to use. Ranging from a simple, if not cool, assault rifle to a harpoon gun that fires drill bits that fling people to their doom and everything in-between. My favourite was the sniper rifle that lets you guide the bullet right into the enemy’s faces before making them explode killing everyone stood next to them. Every weapon has a super charge attack that lets you rain destruction down on everyone stood in your way. For the gunplay alone this game is fantastic.

Now the “skillshots”, the game literally rewards you for killing people in inventive ways. Want to blow someone in half with a shotgun, do you want the top or bottom half. Do you want to melt people with a super charged bullet; can you get two at once? I loved it and hunting down all of them takes a while and a great amount of skill sometimes.

The characters are rather bland but they do have some memorable lines and the banter between them is pretty funny. I liked how they played out and interacted with each other yet they didn’t steal the attention from the action which is the real star of this title. The storyline is standard, a quest for vengeance and hope. Of course it takes place on an alien world in a tourist resort ruined by some and alien world over run by ex-cons and mutants, so a little different there.

As for the world itself, it is outstanding, everything is beautiful and I found myself just staring at the backgrounds and wondering what happened to this place. Also the ability to see the location of previous levels in the distance was something I loved; you could see your progress across the city. The set pieces are awesome, all of them stand out and I am sure you will enjoy just exploring the world around you as you trudge knee deep through the blood and guts of your enemies.

Go out and buy this right now, load it up and play it as soon as you can and you will not be disappointed. If you love action, awesome guns and one liners you will love this game.

Have Fun ^_^

reviewText:
Bulletstorm is a pretty unique FPS with some interesting mechanical ideas and a very over-the-top presentation. The game is too ridiculous to really take seriously, but it is an enjoyable enough romp on the whole, murdering your way through the opposition in increasingly ridiculous, brutal, and creative ways.

If you want to play a FPS which tries to do something different, this is a solid choice for you. If you don't like a lot of swearing, or are of a sensitive disposition, you probably should skip this game, as it is incredibly profane and gratuitously violent.

Grade: B-

reviewText:
“Playing Bulletstorm will make you feel like the Bob Ross of murder”

Bulletstorm is by far my favorite Jason Statham simulator and I’m very happy that it has finally arrived on steam. Upon booting the game up for the first time you might be concerned by the fact that Jason Statham is not actually part of the cast. If you give the game a moment you will find that Jason Statham is engrained into the very mechanics of the game.

“The GDD for Bulletstorm was just a picture of Jason Statham’s face”

Bulletstorm actually encourages you to act more like Jason Statham using the revolutionary “Skillshot System”. The Skillshot system rewards you points to upgrade weapons by killing enemies. The points you earn are based on whether or not Jason Statham would be impressed with how you killed the enemy. For instance, lighting an enemy on fire and letting them die a slow painful death might allot you a handful of points, but if you want more points you need to get creative, you need to think like Jason Statham. Jason Statham would light that guy on fire, wrap him in explosives, and impale him with a rocket powered drill that would send him flying through the air eventually picking up a childhood friend before exploding off in the horizon. The more Statham you are the more points you will get.

“Bulletstorm will hit you like a hefty bag of codeine”

You should definitely get this game.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Bulletstorm is a thrilling ride that hands you a means to erupt in your own maelstrom of chaos within an ever-increasing onslaught of firefighters.  The landscapes are rich with graphical enhancenicity that actually entice you to stop and take in the sights. Excellent play control. Movement can be a little buggy when abutted against elevations or when sliding near impervious objects, and a lack of a jump button is noticable from time to time. The story is generic with no unexpected coiling, but the character acting is done well.  An excess of swearing may cause some discomfort, even among those with potty lids for lips, but at the end of the day it's all in good fun.

Windows Live ruins everything it touches. Worth picking up at a second-hand shop.

I rate this game twenty three shots of rum in a pina colada punch bowl.

reviewText:
A great. Ball to the wall. Duke Nukem style shooter. Full of crude humor. Skill shots. Weapon modifications. Tons of blood and guts and lots... lots... LOTS ... of swearing! A decent casual game. Story is the typical, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ bag did you wrong, you hunt him down and try to kill him, revenge story.

Only issue, GFWL is ♥♥♥♥ and lags the game out sometimes or even crashes it. But apart from that, a truly solid and underrated shooter. I'd recommend it to anyone who's a fan of the over the top action movies with Arnold Schwarzenegger where every bullet misses, but each one you fire in like a miniature nuclear bomb.

reviewText:
Holy ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥. Honestly, when I saw this game and asked my rich friend to buy it for both of us, I did not expect this level of pure ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. HOLY ♥♥♥♥. LIKE JESUS CHRIST. THE AWESOMENESS IS REAL. This game is probably the best first person shooter I've ever played, and despite Metro, a very unique type of first person shooter at that.

Gameplay:
BOOM BOOM BOOM KICK IN THE FACE KICK INTO ELECTRICITY BOOM BOOM BOOM KICK IN FACE KICK INTO CACTUS BOOM BOOM HOLY ♥♥♥♥ING ♥♥♥♥ THIS IS ♥♥♥♥ING ADDICTING.
(Not even kidding, I told myself I would stop playing at 11, and my computer had to crash so I could finally get off at 5 am.)

Story:
Half decent story, enough to give you a reason to have your butt buddies roll with you and still shoot baddies.

Co-op:
If you got multiple, or at least one, this is the game to play with them. You will find so many laughing moments at this game hilariousness and just pure ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. Once, my friend and i tried kicking a guy into a cactus, we completely missed, the guy went onto a platform and another platform coincidentally fell on that guy as soon as he landed on the original platform, and we died laughing.. Literally, we lost the round cause we were laughing so hard.

10/10 would joypuke again.

reviewText: Beneath the incredibly irritating sense of humor (extremely immature jokes throughout with a few legitimately funny ones thrown in for good measure) and pathetic porting (resulting in letterboxing on 4:3 or 16:10 monitors, controls being over-simple, and graphics glitches) lies a surprisingly fun, creative FPS. The interesting Skillshot" system is a blast to play around with as you find increasingly absurd ways to dispose of your enemies
date: and the lush environments and excellent fast-paced combat make for a rather enjoyable experience. Co-op "Horde mode" multiplayer and Echoes mode (where you go through campaign levels for high scores and fast times) add replay value to a fairly short (~8 hour) campaign. This one's worth looking into if you want an FPS that doesn't take itself seriously (though the storyline suggests otherwise)."

reviewText:
This game is hilarious! The one-liners the protagonist has are probably the best I have heard in recent years! In addition to this, while this is a good-old, action-packed shooter where you really need to shoot everything that moves, the game rewards you for being creative.

Earning more points is recommended so that you can buy ammo and upgrade your weapons. However, if you just riddle someone with bullets you only get 10 points. Do that after a kick while they are in the air and that earns you 25. Finish this with a headshot which adds an extra 50. Environmental kills give you high scores and when multiple enemies are killed at once that's also very rewarding.

As you make progress the game unlocks a list of new methods of kills you can perform. I like how they expect you to be more and more creative along the way. In fact, the game's 4-player co-op mode is all about this - in Anarchy you get to shoot enemies who come at you wave after wave. The expectation here is to be more creative so that you can get a higher score. As the new waves are approaching the score level increases gradually.

Story-wise Bulletstorm is a tale of vengeance. Grayson and his bounty hunter fellows are tricked by a powerful general. Gray thinks it's now payback time and does a suicide maneuver with his ship. Both his and the general's ship crashland on an alien planet. While you are looking for the general with your teammate (the only one who survived) you need to get past the local, cannibalistic tribes and the various monsters you encounter.

Some of the vistas the game has look gorgeous. Well, a lot of games use Unreal Engine 3 nowadays but here you can clearly see the extra attention and detail that went into the making of each and every level. The designers really did their best. Cutscenes are frequent, the music is good and Gray's one-liners are awesome!

Now that we are having the summer sale Bulletstorm is a catch! Hope you can grab it, too!

reviewText:
Bulletstorm is an attempt to recreate the atmosphere of the golden age of shooters, back when skill and speed were all that matter and sitting still for 10 seconds meant a quick and certain death.

The gameplay however takes a turn with it's extensive focus on Skill-Shots" rewarding you upgrade experience based on the uniqueness of your kill. This is a fun gimmick at first but once you realize that the core gameplay is based around it you start to feel the grind. Most of the time using your guns is a bad choice as simply shooting someone will only get you a fraction of what throwing someone off a cliff or into the mouth of a man-eating plant would.

The graphics are fairly decent despite the older engine but the dialog sounds like they were written by a 12 year old and the rather extreme amount of curse words feels forced and overdone.

Difficulty wise it really feels like a console game. Playing with a mouse makes even the toughest enemies a breeze.

5$ of fun in a 60$ game."
voteText: 18 of 35 people (51%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A very stupid game, but willfully stupid. The dialogue and presentation are way over the top but everything is wonderfully polished, beautiful, and gleaming. Sound is incredible, music is swelling and motivating, and the entire experience is exaggerated and ridiculous. For all that it is, it really is a very good game.

Unfortunately it suffers from some console-centric design. There are no autosaves - checkpoints only. Subtitles and interface are huge. FOV is way too low and the mouse controls while aiming down the sights are uncontrollably sensitive. This was obviously a game that was promptly forgotten after launch and it suffers for it.

It's a very amusing experience but the poor PC port really does make it unplayable in many frequent scenarios. If you're not squeamish about editing config files and you have a mouse with adjustable DPI or a sniper button then the experience is passably good. Such a shame - this game could be legendary with just a tiny bit more polish but due to this series of tiny oversights most people won't have the patience to massage this game into a salvagable state. If you're a tinkerer then you'll have a good time with this silly shooter.

reviewText: It is a rather good single player FPS game.  It took me about 10 hours to complete it.  It has a very nice combat mechanic that rewards killing enemies in more interesting ways other than just shooting them.  Like Most FPS games, the develoeprs did a poor job of ending the game.  It is basically throwing a lot of BS situations at you, one right after the other in the last parts of the game.  However, up to this point it is a lot of fun.  One other mention is that the game has a fairly mature sense of humor which I quite enjoyed.\n\nThe co-op mode is just a survival death match type of thing, you and a friend vs waves of bad guys.  It is a shame they didn't do a co-op mode for the single player game.  The single player game almost seemds made for a two people to play it together.  Ill keep my eye on this studio for thier next game.

reviewText:
Bulletstorm is a rare breed of game. It's a fast paced, intensely brutal First Person-Shooter with Arcade mechanics.

This game is a joke on the seriousness of the action genre. It has ludicrous dialogue to go along with it's ridiculous premise. But that's the fun of it. If hilarity isn't your cup of tea, it all comes down to the gun play, and that is where this game shines like a diamond. You have seven main weapons, two sub-weapons that are on you at all times and one weapon you can find and pick up. Each weapon is upgradeable by spending skill points you earn by killing. The more inventive you are with your kills, the more points you will earn. Use the weapons given and the environmental hazards around you to rack up a high score. Easy, Normal, Hard, and Insane difficulties are available.

Weapons:
Bonesduster (Shotgun)
Peacemaker Carbine (Assault Rifle)
Penetrator (Drill Gun)
Flailgun (Chain-Mine Launcher)
Head Hunter (Sniper Rifle)
Bouncer (Grenade Launcher)
Screamer (Pistol)

Sub-Weapon:
Energy Leash
Gravity Boots

Misc. Weapon:
Chaingun (Minigun)


Games similar in gameplay include:
Darkness II
Call of Juarez Gunslinger
Hard Reset
Alien Rage - Unlimited.

reviewText:
For all of you who honestly say even now that this game was just poorly recieved: you're wrong. It's terrible. Very few redeeming qualities in the face of all the bad ones.

Pre-release, people hyped it up as a carefree shooter that made fun of super-serious space marine games but on release players saw the game turn into the very thing it was making fun of. Stayed away from on release but as time went on people started giving it more favorable reviews, saying that the gunplay wasn't terrible, and the space lasso was pretty fun. I missed when it was last on sale for $5 so I grabbed it for $5 during this winter sale. Maybe haters aren't completely evil people after all.

The guns all sound powerful, but do terribly little for damage. It was obviously shoddily ported over to PC considering the ludicrous default keyboard bindings. The intense bloom did nothing but cover up the muddy textures that Epic's games are famous for. The enemies are simply bullet sponges most of the time and the allied AI does nothing but aggro the enemies for you. They also have a habit of getting stuck in scripted areas, making certain levels impossible to complete because the character needed for the next scripted event is somewhere a million miles back in the last area. Oh and bloody screen, so real.

Some of the adrenaline-filled on-rails/hyperlinear segments are honestly fun, though. Kicking enemies into spikes and hazards for a load of points is cool, but then it quickly turns into WOW GOOD JOB YOU SHOT MAN HERE 10 PTS POSITIVE FEEDBACK AND REINFORCEMENT. The intro and first few levels do feel like an off-the-rails RIP AND TEAR shooter where you've got a hundred enemies coming at you and you've got lots of power to kill them all, but the action quickly dips to a halt as the player progresses through the story.


All in all, I wouldn't even recommend paying $5 for this game. I'm probably stating facts plenty of people know by now but man this game just left me so angry and disappointed and seeing people say that it's not bad" grinds my gears."

reviewText:
So this one time, my friend and I were sitting down getting this set up and creating a GFWL account for him, registering keys and whatnot. Through some mystical magic, we managed to register both of our keys to one of our GFWL accounts. Beer may have been involved.

We contacted GFWL support, and notified them of the issue. After several calls, I provided photos of the keys and their respective steam accounts. I was then told that they would need to contact the publisher and request an additional key, as well as their DBAs dropping a precision bunker buster on one of the two keys that got registered to my GFWL account.

I checked back once or twice a month. Then once a month. Eventually down to once every other month. I was given the option at one point to buy the game again on the GFWL marketplace and it would be reimbursed, but my faith in that process being timely was obliterated at that point.

And then one day, OVER A YEAR FROM MY INITIAL COMPLAINT, I received a phone call at 8am on a Saturday. This is GFWL support. We've fixed your account and emailed you an additional key."

"No s***?"

We still haven't managed to sit down and play the game through
date: but I played for an hour or so and really enjoyed the d*** jokes.\n\n8/10"

reviewText:
Bulletstorm is a rare breed of game. It's a fast paced, intensely brutal First Person-Shooter with Arcade mechanics.

This game is a joke on the seriousness of the action genre. It has ludicrous dialogue to go along with it's ridiculous premise. But that's the fun of it. If hilarity isn't your cup of tea, it all comes down to the gun play, and that is where this game shines like a diamond. You have seven main weapons, two sub-weapons that are on you at all times and one weapon you can find and pick up. Each weapon is upgradeable by spending skill points you earn by killing. The more inventive you are with your kills, the more points you will earn. Use the weapons given and the environmental hazards around you to rack up a high score. Easy, Normal, Hard, and Insane difficulties are available.

Weapons:
Bonesduster (Shotgun)
Peacemaker Carbine (Assault Rifle)
Penetrator (Drill Gun)
Flailgun (Chain-Mine Launcher)
Head Hunter (Sniper Rifle)
Bouncer (Grenade Launcher)
Screamer (Pistol)

Sub-Weapon:
Energy Leash
Gravity Boots

Misc. Weapon:
Chaingun (Minigun)


Games similar in gameplay include:
Darkness II
Call of Juarez Gunslinger
Hard Reset
Alien Rage - Unlimited.

reviewText: A surprisingly enjoyable effort from Epic. The whole points system, wherein you get points for performing an assortment of kills and then use the points to level up, is quite an entertaining gameplay mechanic, and while it can occasionally become cumbersome pausing the game every so often to look up kills you haven't yet executed (ho, ho), it never really hindered the experience for me. The set pieces are bright and pretty, and a stark departure from that other Epic staple, the Gears of War series. Definitely recommend this one, if only to experience a relatively unique take on the ol' FPS yarn.\n\n(6/10)

reviewText:
This game is AWESOME!

This game packs so many new ideas and original gameplay, you honestly feel like you're playing a totally different sort of FPS.
This game is not just about point and shoot. It also involves much creativity, and gives the player many options on how to kill the enemy. Aswell as an arsenal of guns you also have a 'whip-like' leash enabling you to pull and throw enemies any way you see fit. Enemies will go into slow motion once you leash them and then you can decide on how to kill them. Kicking enemies into plants, bombs, the sea, off cliffs, and into objects MADE this game.
The sniper rifle was also much fun. You got to fire, and then steer the bullet to It's final destination. That's something I'd like to see in future games.

I was hooked on this game from start to finish, and my only regret was not playing it sooner. The storyline is pretty epic, and it ends well for Bulletstorm 2. Let's hope it happens one day.

reviewText: Bulletstorm is unlike most of the copy-paste FPS clones on the market, thankfully. If you're looking for yet another Iraq War simulator (BF, MW, CoD clone), then look elsewhere. Bulletstorm features a unique combat system that breaks up the otherwise fast paced gameplay with shooting-gallery skill shots and environment kills (using abilities similar to Force Push and Pull, if you will). Otherwise if I had to compare Bulletstorm to existing games then I would say that it feels something like mix of the first Unreal single player campaign (original, fun weapons and beautiful, exotic environments) and Gears of War (limited cover system, regenerating health, testosterone-laden characters). While the narrative is oftentimes simple, it is thoroughly enjoyable with some great scripted sequences – including some of the best boss fights that I have played so far.\n\nMy only gripe about the combat system is the lack of a deeper combo system (akin to SSX tricks); as it stands you are only scored on the last attack type that you performed, even though chains of attacks are possible. Multiplayer is limited to 4 player co-op in a survival/arena match where you attempt to outscore each other (while surviving); which is interesting but falls flat after a while. It's a shame that there's no co-op campaign, as this game seems built for one. While the game is a port from a console version, Bulletstorm is about as good of a port as one can wish for on a PC - and that's coming from me, probably the staunchest opponent of console-to-PC ports you will meet. It's a shame that the sequel was cancelled - as this game definitely deserves one, if nothing else to tie up loose ends in the campaign story.

reviewText:
A really nice fresh take on an FPS, just finished it so i'll recommend it :D
PROS
+Amazing combat, You'll love using skillshots and different ways to kill your enemy
+Good storyline, Defnitely not the best but that's not what Bulletstorm is for it's just there to keep you going.
+I enjoyed using the dropkits to change my guns and upgrade them
+The dialogue for this game is hilarious, The interaction between the characters will make you smile.
CONS
-The combat can get a bit stale at times but that's only if you keep spamming the same skillshot.

Final Notes and Score
-I actually cared for the story in this and if you do to you'll probably enjoy it more.
-Some of the boss fights are actually quite fun and some can get quite challenging.
-One of the best comedy games i've ever played. (If that makes any sense.)

Final Score: 8.5/10

reviewText: Wonderfully entertaining. Quite fantastic in its scope and gameplay. Love the slide kick move and all the neat experience mechanics. It's really a wonderful game. The story meanders a bit, and some of balance is not even (goes from relatively easy to extremely punishing at a couple points), and it's definitely not the end of the story. But the game is gorgeous and the voice acting is wonderful. I never had a lot of problems with the squad mechanics, and the levels and backstory were very interesting.  It would be a crime for there not to be a sequel. I recomend this for anyone looking for a shooter that plays with the norm and mixes things up a bit, without trying to reinvent the wheel.

reviewText:
Bulletstorm is a pretty awesome game, and I think you should buy it if you think 8 hours of fun is worth the price. However, there are some dissapointments. The main one being Games for Windows live. Really, I started this game and immidiately it started begging me to use the platform I hate oh so much. It was a lot of hassle too; asking me to login, update, then login to update, followed by update to login. At one point I started hoping Microsoft employees would run around and I would be able to brutally murder them (as you will A LOT in Bulletstorm). Also, it gets kind of repetive. Yes, it's all about ♥♥♥-kicking, yes it's all about being an inter-stellar murder machine, but after 2 hours of obviously shouting that to my face I GET IT.

But really, if 8 hour of ♥♥♥-kicking, violent murder and manliness is your kind of thing: buy it. It's painkiller good, and it's awfully satisfying. It might not be long, it might not be complex, but if you're anything like me (a real man) you'll absolutely love it. Besides, 8 hours of 'in your face' agression therapy; who wouldn't want that!

p.s. Only virtually would I like to violently murder Microsoft employees, and only after forcing me to use Games for Windows Live. No Microsoft employees were hurt during or after my playthrough of Bulletstorm™

reviewText:
So this one time, my friend and I were sitting down getting this set up and creating a GFWL account for him, registering keys and whatnot. Through some mystical magic, we managed to register both of our keys to one of our GFWL accounts. Beer may have been involved.

We contacted GFWL support, and notified them of the issue. After several calls, I provided photos of the keys and their respective steam accounts. I was then told that they would need to contact the publisher and request an additional key, as well as their DBAs dropping a precision bunker buster on one of the two keys that got registered to my GFWL account.

I checked back once or twice a month. Then once a month. Eventually down to once every other month. I was given the option at one point to buy the game again on the GFWL marketplace and it would be reimbursed, but my faith in that process being timely was obliterated at that point.

And then one day, OVER A YEAR FROM MY INITIAL COMPLAINT, I received a phone call at 8am on a Saturday. This is GFWL support. We've fixed your account and emailed you an additional key."

"No s***?"

We still haven't managed to sit down and play the game through
date: but I played for an hour or so and really enjoyed the d*** jokes.\n\n8/10"

Bulletstorm isn't your typical Sci-Fi FPS shooter it combines elements of weapon usage & the leash useage which is more of a tool then a weapon. All in all I give it 3 1/2 stars outta 5.

column16: decent character development and story. They graphics lean towards the prettier looking side of the spectrum and the score is enjoyable although forgettable. Gameplay is a mix between Gears of War and Painkiller - fairly linear levels but they are straighforward fun and the world was pretty immersive for me. There's no multiplayer but there is a CoOp mode where you and a friend can rank in kills together. Altogether you are looking at 1-2 playthroughs before potentially getting bored and moving on. It's the standard ~8 hour game. This game also runs on Games for Windows application so be warned.\n\nOverall

reviewText: Bulletstorm is very fun to play. Kill with Skill, why nobody had done this before? Although pretty blunt and really fun, this is the true successor of the late Duke Nukem. As weapons are quite different and as you choose from a selection at start-up, the game has a good replay value so you can start by choosing different weapons such as for instance the head trap of the Saw movie (and make it explode). Or take fireworks to see the guys fly and explode into beautiful sparks. Each impact on the enemy is managed as well so you can shoot any parts of the body and have a different reactions (and various bonuses). The game is not too repetitive either in terms of worlds and different enemies, and there's a background story to discover. In short, a game very cool game to let loose!

reviewText:
Bulletstorm is an immature, tongue-in-cheek game that while is short and lacks any major replayability can still be fun. Sometimes just blowing crap up can be fun, and Bulletstorm proves that quite nicely. With jokes involving male organs that generally backfire, and sarcastic remarks across the board it's a game that just doesn't take itself too seriously and is absolutely great that way.

Like most titles with Epic's involvement it is crude, rude, and just something to laugh at. The characters themselves are fairly unlikable across the board (to which they should be, these guys aren't role models), but still prove to be amusing one way or another.

The combo system and point system is the center of what tries to make Bulletstorm a replayable game. Run through, get a better score than your other runs. Not a bad concept, but without the active competition brought on by seeing other people there, there's not as much of a rush.

reviewText: Wow, what an action packed game! The action never stopped there were so many ways to kill the enemy. The game rewards you for the unique ways of killing. The story was great, the level artwork look awesome and great adds alot of detail to the game. You can wipe out a group of bad guys with a push of a button. Each gun has 2 firing modes, one charges the gun up for a devastating impact and the other just shoots as normal. The downfall with this game was it was too short for my liking, I wish there was more to the story since multiplayer is dead unless you have friends to play with.The changing of weapons took some time to get used to since you can have the main weapons and one other weapon with you at all times. There is a great deal of humor in the dialog of the game which made it really funny at times. There is a challenge mode were you face a bunch of enemies at certain parts of the story and see how well you kill them to become ranked on the leaderboards. The game is excellent!

reviewText: Actually a blast to play, though I have doubts about getting much replay out of it.  The pacing was perfect all the way through, the dialog and voice acting were as good as you could wish for given the somewhat ludicrous story.  Now I say ludicrous story, but this isn't necessarily a bad thing for this game.  It doesn't take itself seriously enough to be bashed for having a B-movie plot, and the character development of all of the characters more than makes up for it in the entertainment factor.  The graphics are fantastic when everything is maxxed out, no hiccups or glitches.  The controls have a good connected feel to it, not as much of a console-controller-port feel like a lot of games have nowadays.  Menus are snappy, levels load fast.  I'd give it an A-; it would have more if it had more meat to the multiplayer, or a co-op campaign would have A+'d it right away.

reviewText:
For all of you who honestly say even now that this game was just poorly recieved: you're wrong. It's terrible. Very few redeeming qualities in the face of all the bad ones.

Pre-release, people hyped it up as a carefree shooter that made fun of super-serious space marine games but on release players saw the game turn into the very thing it was making fun of. Stayed away from on release but as time went on people started giving it more favorable reviews, saying that the gunplay wasn't terrible, and the space lasso was pretty fun. I missed when it was last on sale for $5 so I grabbed it for $5 during this winter sale. Maybe haters aren't completely evil people after all.

The guns all sound powerful, but do terribly little for damage. It was obviously shoddily ported over to PC considering the ludicrous default keyboard bindings. The intense bloom did nothing but cover up the muddy textures that Epic's games are famous for. The enemies are simply bullet sponges most of the time and the allied AI does nothing but aggro the enemies for you. They also have a habit of getting stuck in scripted areas, making certain levels impossible to complete because the character needed for the next scripted event is somewhere a million miles back in the last area. Oh and bloody screen, so real.

Some of the adrenaline-filled on-rails/hyperlinear segments are honestly fun, though. Kicking enemies into spikes and hazards for a load of points is cool, but then it quickly turns into WOW GOOD JOB YOU SHOT MAN HERE 10 PTS POSITIVE FEEDBACK AND REINFORCEMENT. The intro and first few levels do feel like an off-the-rails RIP AND TEAR shooter where you've got a hundred enemies coming at you and you've got lots of power to kill them all, but the action quickly dips to a halt as the player progresses through the story.


All in all, I wouldn't even recommend paying $5 for this game. I'm probably stating facts plenty of people know by now but man this game just left me so angry and disappointed and seeing people say that it's not bad" grinds my gears."

reviewText:
I like it to make Pro Con Lists instead of a normal Review. Enjoy.

Pro:
+ Good Keyboard Controlls
+ XBox360 Controller fully supported
+ Fantastic (!!) Soundtrack
+ Good Voiceactors
+ A 2011 Console Port with great graphics for this time.
+ It's the first game of the Polish Game Developer People Can Fly and for that it's not bad.

Contra:
- Weird Dialogues with childish cursing and flatt lines
- Grinding (Skillshots Farming) to imense. Less Skillshots would have been better
- The Volume of Soundeffects, Prerendered-Videos and Ingame-Videos are often that different that you get a shock if somethin explodes and that you can't really hear everything what a char says
- In the End: It's a classic shooter. So you have to clean an area and then move on. It's a little boring if in one area new enemies are coming for a couple of minutes.
- Weird ending (in fact weird story)

Final words: So is it a good game? I would say no. Even i changed the difficulty while i was played. I think the game was to long (normal playthroughtime 9-11h, mine 15h). The story is nonsens, the grinding and some parts are to long, but the action is over-the-top and makes fun.

Only if you really like shooter (like me) you can play it. Anyone else should play good Shooters instead, e.g. the Bioshock Triology.

reviewText:
Good gawd man! So metacritic gave this game an 82/100. Christ! What has this world come to? I've never played such a brain dead FPS with a who gives a fart worst than C-grade Hollywood storyline. I would personally give this game something below 50/100.

I swear! I have never had to break up playing a game in portions before! It's taken me 11 hours to complete this game. But playing for 3 hours feels like an eternity! I must have played this game in approximately 1/4 portions. Taking a few months break inbetween.

I don't want to be picky on the Unreal Engine for a gazzilionth time, but this game is the epitome of all your standard Unreal Engine crap. I haven't really played Duke Nukem Forever yet nor BioShock 2, but I have this feeling I won't even be able to tell the difference between these games and Bulletstorm.

One of the highlights about this game is the kicking right? I mean that's cool yeah? Well sorry to disappoint, but it's nowhere near as fun as kicking down doors or enemies in the classic game Return To Castle Wolfenstein. They got the feel" of it wrong!

There are 7 Act's in the game. Each with a few chapters. Act 0 was sort of okay. But Act 1 till about 5 and a half was just an atrocious nightmare. Non stop corny jokes and attitude. I feel like a 6th grader wrote the personalities for the characters.

There are these things called "skillpoints". It's supposed to be a feature highlight of the game. This is a very bad idea. It's just a "tracking system". Without trying and so long as you constantly use multiple weapons
date: you'll achieve over 90 of about 130 of these skillpoints anyways. I didn't even give a fiddley fart about them.\n\nTo explain this game properly
recommended: imagine a 5 min combat scenario. You kick someone into spikes. You slide kick. You use your stupid electric whip. You use the secondary function of the 3 (out of about 6) weapons you're allowed to carry at a time. You use the environment to kick explosive barrels into enemies. THAT'S ALL YOU CAN DO! Now ... multiply that 5 min combat round
hoursPlayed: a few hundred times until you've REPEATED IT FOR 11 FRIGGEN HOURS !!! YEEAA !!!\n\nGames For Windows Live is gone. Which doesn't make this game any better. This game is really broken without GFWL !!! But when it was around
voteText: I did have the opportunity to play the coop. It's basically like what I described in that 5 min combat thing above.\n\nThe only thing I can say that's been good with this game
helpfulPercent: is the nice environments. It's just a shame that you're just running forward that there's no time to really admire the level design. I'd even go as far as saying the level designers are victims somewhat.\n\nIf you like non-stop shooting action games like the single player of Call Of Duty 2 onwards and possibly the first F.E.A.R game. Then you may like this game. Otherwise stay away from this EA polished garbage. I've seen smaller game development teams that have created better than this commercial piece of crap! I mean seriously! It took hundreds of people to create Bulletstorm? LOL !!!"

reviewText:
A very stupid game, but willfully stupid. The dialogue and presentation are way over the top but everything is wonderfully polished, beautiful, and gleaming. Sound is incredible, music is swelling and motivating, and the entire experience is exaggerated and ridiculous. For all that it is, it really is a very good game.

Unfortunately it suffers from some console-centric design. There are no autosaves - checkpoints only. Subtitles and interface are huge. FOV is way too low and the mouse controls while aiming down the sights are uncontrollably sensitive. This was obviously a game that was promptly forgotten after launch and it suffers for it.

It's a very amusing experience but the poor PC port really does make it unplayable in many frequent scenarios. If you're not squeamish about editing config files and you have a mouse with adjustable DPI or a sniper button then the experience is passably good. Such a shame - this game could be legendary with just a tiny bit more polish but due to this series of tiny oversights most people won't have the patience to massage this game into a salvagable state. If you're a tinkerer then you'll have a good time with this silly shooter.
